alert.note: Alert for Spartanburg (South Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Greenville-Spartanburg (Western North Carolina and Northwest South Carolina)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued January 09 at 6:39PM EST until January 11 at 9:27PM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT UNTIL 1230 AM EST WEDNESDAY... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. * WHERE...Spartanburg County in Upstate South Carolina. * WHEN...Until 1230 AM EST. * IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring. Low-water crossings are inundated with water and may not be passable. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 635 PM EST, Rain gauges reported rainfall totals of 3 to 5 inches over the past 24 hours and runoff from this heavy rainfall continues to produce flooding around the county. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Spartanburg, Greer, Boiling Springs SC, Woodruff, Duncan, Lyman, Pacolet, Landrum, Cowpens, Wellford, Inman, Mayo, Roebuck, Chesnee, Pacolet Mills, Campobello, Reidville, USC Upstate, Moore and Cedar Springs. - Flooding is most likely along the South Pacolet River near Campobello and Lawsons Fork Creek near Spartanburg. High flows will continue especially along Old Mill Road and Depot Street along the South Pacolet River. Lawsons Fork Creek will likely flood locations along and near Heathwood Drive in Spartanburg. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: When it is safe to do so, please report flooding threatening roads or property to the National Weather Service Greenville-Spartanburg by calling toll free, 1, 800, 2 6 7, 8 1 0 1, by posting on our Facebook page, or via Twitter using hashtag NWSGSP. Your message should describe the specific location where impacts occurred and the depth of flooding observed. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding.
